content.title: LHC vs Planck Energy: How Far Are We From Quantum Gravity?
content.abstract: A quantitative comparison of the Large Hadron Collider's capabilities to the Planck energy scale, demonstrating why direct experimental tests of quantum gravity are far beyond current technology—and what our best particle colliders can actually probe.
content.problem_statement: The LHC operates at 14 TeV center-of-mass energy. How does this compare to the Planck energy E_P ≈ 1.22 × 10¹⁹ GeV? What would it take to probe quantum gravity directly?

step_1.title: Calculate LHC to Planck Energy Ratio
step_1.interpretation: LHC energy is 10⁻¹⁵ of the Planck scale—a quadrillion times too low!
step_1.gap: We need to bridge 15 orders of magnitude to reach Planck energy

step_2.title: Length Scale Probed by LHC
step_2.interpretation: LHC probes distances 10¹⁵ times larger than Planck length
step_2.context: LHC sees 10⁻²⁰ m; Planck length is 10⁻³⁵ m; atom is 10⁻¹⁰ m

step_3.title: What Energy Would We Need?
step_3.calculation: To reach E_P with protons: need γ = E_P/(m_p c²) = 1.22×10¹⁹/0.938 ≈ 1.3 × 10¹⁹
step_3.lorentz_factor: Protons must move at v = c(1 - 1/(2γ²)) ≈ c(1 - 3×10⁻³⁹)
step_3.interpretation: Essentially indistinguishable from light speed—but astronomically higher energy

step_4.title: Hypothetical Planck-Energy Collider Size
step_4.scaling: For circular collider: E ∝ B × R where B is magnetic field, R is radius
step_4.lhc_parameters: LHC: 7 TeV, R = 4.3 km, B = 8.3 Tesla
step_4.comparison: This is 0.8 light-years! Further than nearest star Alpha Centauri (4.4 ly)
step_4.conclusion: A Planck-energy circular collider with current magnets would span a significant fraction of interstellar space

step_5.title: Energy in Macroscopic Terms
step_5.comparison_2: = 0.55 MWh of electricity (powers average home for 20 days)
step_5.comparison_3: = Kinetic energy of a 1-ton car at 6,300 km/h
step_5.total_lhc: Two beams = 672 MJ ≈ 160 kg TNT equivalent (but LHC is 14 TeV total)
step_5.key_point: Individual Planck-energy particles are feasible in terms of energy—the problem is concentrating it in 10⁻¹⁹ m

step_6.title: Cosmic Ray Comparison
step_6.interpretation: Highest-energy cosmic rays are still 10⁸ times below Planck
step_6.gzk_cutoff: GZK limit (5×10¹⁰ GeV) is where cosmic rays scatter off CMB
step_6.nature_cannot: Even nature's most extreme accelerators fall 10⁸ short of Planck energy

why_so_far.explanation: The Planck scale is set by G, ℏ, c—gravity's extreme weakness (G ~ 10⁻¹¹ in SI units) pushes E_P astronomically high
why_so_far.anthropic_view: If Planck scale were lower, black holes would form at lower energies, disrupting chemistry
why_so_far.physics_view: The hierarchy between electroweak (~100 GeV) and Planck (~10¹⁹ GeV) is a mystery

what_can_lhc_do: Tests Standard Model to part-per-million accuracy
Searches for new particles up to ~few TeV mass
Cannot directly probe quantum gravity—too low energy by 10¹⁵
indirect_approaches: Precision tests may reveal quantum gravity corrections at 10⁻¹⁷ level
Rare decays might show Planck-suppressed operators
Black hole production in large extra dimension scenarios (not seen)
Graviton emission if extra dimensions exist (constrained)

future_colliders.fcc_hh: Future Circular Collider (100 km): 100 TeV center-of-mass → still 10⁻¹⁴ × E_P
future_colliders.muon_collider: 10 TeV muons → cleaner but still far from Planck
future_colliders.plasma_wakefield: Currently ~10 GeV in meters; theoretical limit unclear
future_colliders.fundamental_limit: No known technology path to Planck energies in controlled settings

key_results: LHC energy is 10⁻¹⁵ of Planck energy—quadrillion times too low
LHC probes 10⁻²⁰ m; Planck length is 10⁻³⁵ m—gap of 10¹⁵
A Planck-scale circular collider would be ~0.8 light-years in circumference
Even highest cosmic rays (10¹¹ GeV) are 10⁸ below Planck
Direct quantum gravity experiments require new physics or new ideas

Understand scale of challenge for quantum gravity experiments

Appreciate gap between current technology and Planck scale
